title: UAW and GM ratify 4-year contract, end 40-day strike
text:
The longest strike at General Motors in 50 years is finally over.





After a 40-day stalemate between GM and the United Auto Workers union, some 48-thousand production workers will soon be back on the job at 30 U.S. factories.





The union and GM reps overwhelmingly ratified the deal late Friday.





The new 4-year contract includes a mix of wage increases, annual lump-sum payments, and an 11-thousand dollar singing bonus for new hires.





But it also allows GM to close three plants that manufactured transmissions and GM vehicles that were slow to sell.

Analysts estimate the strike cost GM more than 2-billion dollars.





And the U.S. Department of Labor reported the strike will likely slash U.S. job growth by at least 46,000 during the month of October, when workers on the picket line were considered unemployed.
